title: 110_hr3469
content:
The Act titled "America's Border Security Act of 2007" includes provisions for technological assets. The Act "America's Border Security Act of 2007" mandates increased use of Department of Defense equipment like unmanned aerial vehicles and radars to aid in surveillance at US borders to prevent illegal immigration. Within 6 months of enactment, a report assessing risks and current equipment use must be submitted to Congress. The Act mandates increased use of Department of Defense equipment for border surveillance, including a pilot program for unmanned aerial vehicles along the US-Canada border. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2008 through 2012. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2008 through 2012 to carry out subsection (a). The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to construct border control facilities, including roads and vehicle barriers, to achieve operational control of US borders. Quarterly progress reports to Congress are required, and appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2008 through 2012. Additionally, the Secretary can construct new ports of entry and improve existing ones, as well as implement secure communication measures. SEC. 5. SECURE COMMUNICATION.

The Secretary of Homeland Security will develop a plan to enhance satellite communication for Border Patrol agents and other agencies for clear and secure communication. This includes communication between agents, stations, residents in remote areas, and other law enforcement agencies.

SEC. 6. UNMANNED AERIAL VEHICLES. SEC. 6. UNMANNED AERIAL VEHICLES.

The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to acquire and maintain at least 5 unmanned aerial vehicles and related equipment for patrolling the U.S. international borders. This includes additional sensors, critical spares, satellite command and control, and other necessary operational support equipment. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2008 and 2009 to fund these acquisitions. The Secretary of Homeland Security is mandated to develop and implement an aerial surveillance program using unmanned aerial vehicles to enhance border security with Canada and Mexico. The goal is continuous monitoring of each mile of the international borders. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to assess and consult on the feasibility of using various aerial surveillance technologies to address border threats, including consulting with the Secretary of Defense and the Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration for safety and implementation issues. The program will include the use of aerial surveillance technologies in different terrains and areas along international borders. The Secretary of Homeland Security is evaluating the use of aerial surveillance technologies near the US border to assess previous experiences, cost-effectiveness, and concerns related to border security. The program allows for continued operation of these technologies while assessing their effectiveness, with a report to Congress due within 180 days. The Secretary of Homeland Security is establishing the Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program to enhance border security with unmanned aerial vehicles, cameras, sensors, and other technologies. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the program. The Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program includes integrated technologies for automated surveillance, with motion sensor alerts activating cameras, cameras not requiring manual operation, flexible camera views, video accessible at designated centers, standardized data collection, and future remote surveillance technology. The Program aims to integrate future remote surveillance technology, develop performance measures to evaluate effectiveness, streamline site selection processes, expand shared use of structures for surveillance technology, and deploy nonpermanent or mobile standards. The Secretary of Homeland Security will deploy nonpermanent or mobile surveillance platforms to increase mobility and identify border intrusions. A report to Congress is required within 1 year of implementing the Integrated and Automated Surveillance Program, including program description and recommendations. Standards will be developed to evaluate contractor performance for the program. The Inspector General of the Department reviews new contracts over $5,000,000 for compliance with cost requirements, performance objectives, and schedules. Findings are reported to the Secretary of Homeland Security and then to Congress within 30 days. The Inspector General of the Department reviews contracts over $5,000,000 for compliance. Findings are reported to the Secretary of Homeland Security and Congress. Authorization of appropriations is provided for necessary actions. SEC. 8. HIRING AND TRAINING OF BORDER AND TRANSPORTATION SECURITY PERSONNEL. During fiscal year 2008, the Secretary of Homeland Security shall increase the number of full-time agents and support staff in the Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforcement by 400, and in the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection by 600. The Secretary is authorized to waive any limitation on personnel to fulfill these requirements. Ongoing training will be provided to ensure proficiency levels of personnel to protect the borders of the United States. The Secretary of Homeland Security must prepare and submit a National Border Security Plan to Congress by January 31 each year. The plan includes a vulnerability assessment of each port of entry on the northern and southern borders, with the option to establish port security coordinators for assistance.
